Title: Synthesis of nano-TiO2/diatomite composite and its photocatalytic degradation of gaseous formaldehyde
Author: Guangxin Zhang Zhiming Sun Yongwei Duan Ruixin Ma Shuilin Zheng
PII: S0169-4332(17)30879-6 DOI: http://dx.doi.org/doi:10.1016/j.apsusc.2017.03.198 Reference: APSUSC 35574
To appear in: APSUSC
Received date: 9-2-2017 Revised date: 15-3-2017 Accepted date: 22-3-2017
Please cite this article as: G. Zhang, Z. Sun, Y. Duan, R. Ma, S. Zheng, Synthesis of nanoTiO2/diatomite composite and its photocatalytic degradation of gaseous formaldehyde, Applied Surface Science (2017), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.apsusc.2017.03.198
This is a PDF file of an unedited manuscript that has been accepted for publication. As a service to our customers we are providing this early version of the manuscript. The manuscript will undergo copyediting, typesetting, and review of the resulting proof before it is published in its final form. Please note that during the production process errors may be discovered which could affect the content, and all legal disclaimers that apply to the journal pertain.

Highlights
 TiO2/diatomite composite was synthesized by hydrolysis deposition method.  The composite displayed higher photocatalytic performance for formaldehyde.
 The dispersion effect of diatomite was a key factor for high photoactivity.
 The composite is a promising photocatalyst for the indoor air purification.

1
Synthesis of nano-TiO2/diatomite composite and its photocatalytic
degradation of gaseous formaldehyde
Guangxin Zhang, Zhiming Sun*, Yongwei Duan, Ruixin Ma, Shuilin Zheng*
School of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, China University of Mining & Technology (Beijing),
Beijing 100083, PR China
*Corresponding authors. Fax: +86 10 6233 9920
E-mail addresses: zhimingsun@cumtb.edu.cn (Z. Sun), shuilinzheng8@gmail.com (S. Zheng)
Abstract.
The TiO2/diatomite composite was synthesized through a mild hydrolysis of titanyl sulfate. The prepared composite was characterized by X-ray diffraction, N2 adsorption-desorption, scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, X-ray photoelectron
spectroscopy and UV-vis diffused reflectance spectroscopy. The results demonstrate that the
anatase TiO2 nanopartilces anchored on the surface of diatomite with Ti-O-Si bonds between diatomite and TiO2. The photodegradation of gaseous formaldehyde under UV irradiation by the TiO2/diatomite composite was s udied under various operating conditions, including relative humidity, illumination intensity and catalyst amount, which have significant
influence on the degradation process. The TiO2/diatomite composite exhibited better photocatalytic activity than pure TiO2, which could be attributed to the favourable nanoparticles dispersibility and strong formaldehyde adsorption capacity. In addition, the
composite exhibited outstanding reusability over five cycles. The TiO2/diatomite composite shows great promising application foreground in formaldehyde degradation.
Keywords: TiO2; Diatomite; Formaldehyde; Photocatalysis
*Manuscript Click here to view linked References

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Pollutants decontamination has gained increased research attention because of people’s
growing concern on physical health [1-5]. Formaldehyde has been considered as one of the
most serious air pollutants, which is applied to wood, textile, chemical industry fields, etc [6,
7]. Formaldehyde is a colorless, toxic, volatile organic compound [8, 9]. Common emission
sources of indoor formaldehyde are the widely used building and decorative materials such as
furniture, foams, plywood, paints, and textiles [7, 10, 11]. The release of formaldehyde from
these materials has a long-term period. Living in the formaldehyde environment with
concentrations exceeding safety standard will cause quite a few sicknesses such as immune
dysfunction, throat irritation, headache, coughing, and even the risk of cancer [12, 13].
Therefore, effective removal of indoor formaldehyde is of special interest and has great
importance.
There are many approaches to remove the formaldehyde, such as adsorption [9, 14, 15],
catalytic oxidation [16-24], plasma technology [25, 26] and chemical absorption [27]. As a
simple and effective method, physical adsorption is often used to remove formaldehyde.
However, the adsorbents such as activated carbon [28] and porous materials [29] have to be
changed with high frequency due to their limited adsorption capability, easy desorption and
short lifetime [30]. In comparison, photocatalytic oxidation has gained considerable attention
because of its high efficiency and non-pollution [31].
Among the photocatalyst semiconductors, TiO2 is a widely used photocatalyst due to its strong oxidation performance, lower cost and non-toxicity [32]. The TiO2 photocatalytic oxidation process has been used in wastewater treatment [33-35], air purification [36-39],
hydrogen production [40] and so on. However, in spite of the fact that TiO2 photocatalysis has the above advantages, the application of TiO2 nanoparticles is limited due to its easy aggregation and low adsorption capacity [41]. Over the past years, the design and synthesis of
mineral supporting TiO2 nanoparticles have been intensively investigated [42-46]. Wang et al. [47] reported that TiO2/diatomite composite prepared by sol-gel method has increasing degradation efficiency for Rhodamine B. Sun et al. [48] proved that the prepared
nano-TiO2/diatomite has strong reducing ability, and it showed high photocatalytic reduction
Ac ce
pt ed
M an
us cr
ip t
of aqueous Cr (VI). Other natural minerals, such as montmorillonite [49], attapulgite [50] and
zeolite [51], were also used to remove a broad range of organic pollutants. However, most of
the previous research has focused on the degradation of aqueous-phase pollutants, such as
dyes, phenol and antibiotics. Few studies paid attention to the degradation of gaseous
pollutants. As far as we know, the photocatalytic oxidation of formaldehyde by the
TiO2/diatomite composite has not been reported.
In this work, the nano-TiO2/diatomite was prepared using the hydrolysis deposition of titanyl sulfate. The microstructure and properties of the composite were systematically
studied. Gaseous formaldehyde was used for evaluating the photoactivity of the composite.
Various parameters affecting the photocatalytic properties of composite were also discussed.

sections.heading: 2.1. Preparation of TiO2/diatomite composite
sections.text:
The diatomite (Jilin, China) was used as support in the preparation of the
nano-TiO2/diatomite composite. Table 1 shows the main chemical compositions of diatomite. Firstly, 1 M TiOSO4 solution was prepared. A certain amount of TiOSO4 powders were dissolved in deionized water, and then heated at 60 ℃ under constant stirring until the solution
was transparent. The diatomite suspensions were mixed with sulfuric acid and stoichiometric
amounts of prepared TiOSO4 solution under vigorous stirring. The theoretical loading amount of TiO2 was 45 wt. % (the mass ratio of TiO2 to diatomite). The ICP-AES analysis showed that TiO2 content was 30.66%, which is very closed to the theoretical amount of TiO2 in the composite (31.03%). Subsequently, diluted ammonia was used for adjusting the pH of
mixture to 4.5. The white precipitate was filtrated and dried afterward. Finally, the dried
powders were calcinated at 550 ℃ for 2 h in air. Different loading amount of TiO2 (25%、 35%、55%、65%) was prepared by the same method. Pure TiO2 was prepared through the same method except that diatomite was not added. All chemicals were analytical grade and
deionized water was used throughout this study.

sections.heading: 2.2. Characterization
sections.text:
The D8 ADVANCE X-ray power diffractometer (Bruker, German) was used to detect the
phase compositions of the samples using Cu Kα radiation. The BET specific surface area and
pore structural parameters were measured using JW-BK nitrogen adsorption apparatus (China).
The morphologies of samples were collected by SU8010 field-emission scanning electron
microscopy (SEM, Hitachi, Japan) and Tecnai G2 F20 transmission electron microscopy
(TEM, FEI, USA). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was measured on an
X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (Thermo Escalab 250Xi) using Al Kα radiation. The C 1s
(284.8 eV) was used to calibrate the peak positions of the elements. Ultraviolet and visible
spectrophotometer was used to measure the UV-Vis absorption spectra.

sections.heading: 2.3. Photocatalytic activity
sections.text:
The photo-activities of samples were evaluated in a photocatalytic reactor (250 L, Hunan
Huasi Intrument Co. Ltd., China). The schematic diagram is shown in Fig.1. 1.0 g of
photocatalyst was dispersed on the glass plate (50 cm×50 cm) and placed in the reactor at
ambient temperature (60% of relative humidity). After sealing the reactor, Formaldehyde
solution was injected into the photoreactor through injection port which was sealed with a
silicone rubber septum. The injection port was heated, making the formaldehyde solution
evaporate rapidly. Meanwhile, a small amount of compressed air import gasification of
formaldehyde into the reactor. Prior to light illumination, the electric fan blew in the dark for
120 min. After illuminating for 90 min by the UV lamps (λ=365 nm), the light was turned off.
The concentration of formaldehyde was analyzed according to the spectrophotometric method
(China National Standard GB/T 18204.26-2000). The constant flow atmospheric sampler was
used for sampling (20 L of gas sampling volume), making the gaseous formaldehyde
dissolved in the absorption liquid. The fundamental is that formaldehyde reacted with
4-amino-3-hydrazino-1,2,4-triazol-5-thiol to form purple compound under oxidation of
potassium periodate in alkaline environment. The absorbance at 550 nm was selected to
Page 7 of 22

calculated the concentration of formaldehyde using UV-vis spectrophotometer. The HCHO concentration blank experiment was 0.974 ± 0.05 mg/m3. The degradation rate of

sections.heading: 3.1. Phase analysis
sections.text:
The XRD patterns of Fig. 2 show the structural information of diatomite, TiO2 and TiO2/diatomite composite. The X-ray powder diffraction pattern of diatomite shows broad amorphous SiO2 features centered at 2θ=21.8° [52]. A few diffraction peaks of quartz can be found in the pattern of diatomite. The pure TiO2 and TiO2/diatomite exhibit diffraction peaks at 25.3°, 37.8°, 48.1°, 53.9°, 55.1° and 62.7°, corresponding to (101), (004), (200), (105),
(211) and (204) of anatase TiO2 (JCPDS 21-1272), respectively. The anatase peak intensity of TiO2/diatomite is lower than that of pristine TiO2 on the basis of its low TiO2 content. The anatase in both TiO2 and TiO2/diatomite showed better crystallinity. No characteristic peaks of rutile are showed in TiO2 and TiO2/diatomite on account of the lower calcination temperature [41]. There is no obvious difference among the TiO2/diatomite composite with different TiO2 loading amount. The average crystallite sizes of TiO2 were calculated using the
Page 8 of 22
Ac ce
pt ed
M
an
us cr
ip t
6
Scherrer equation. Table 2 showed that the pure TiO2 and TiO2/diatomite have similar crystallite size. Generally, the smaller crystallite size of TiO2 is beneficial to the higher photoactivity of photocatalyst [53, 54].
Fig. 2. XRD patterns of diatomite, TiO2 and TiO2/diatomite with different TiO2 loading amount.

sections.heading: 3.2. BET analysis
sections.text:
Fig. 3. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and BJH pore size distribution plots (inset) of diatomite, TiO2 and TiO2/diatomite with different TiO2 loading amount.
The BET specific surface area and pore structural parameters of diatomite, TiO2 and TiO2/diatomite composites were measured using the N2 adsorption-desorption method. As
Page 9 of 22
Ac ce
pt
ed
M an
us cr
ip t
7
can be seen from Fig. 3, the isotherms of TiO2 exhibited a type Ⅳ isotherm with a H2 hysteresis loop, which is the characteristic of mesoporous material. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of diatomite showed a IUPAC type Ⅱ isotherms, indicating
the presence of macropores in the diatomite [55]. The TiO2/diatomite composites displayed type IV isotherms with an overlap of H2 and H3 hysteresis loops, resulting from bottle-ink
and slit-like pores, respectively. Such hysteresis is related to the depositing of TiO2 nanoparticles on the surface of diatomite. The BJH pore size distribution plots of TiO2 and TiO2/diatomite composites show that the pores center on the size range of 3 to 5 nm, which is benefit for the adsorption of organic pollutants. The values of the BET specific surface area
and pore structural parameters of samples are showed in Table 2. The pure TiO2 presents the minimum average pore size (4.5 nm) and the maximum surface area (63.0 m 2 /g) and pore volume (0.113 cm 3 /g) owing to its smaller crystal size and abundant mesoporous structure.
According to Table 2, both the surface area and pore volume of TiO2/diatomite are larger than that of diatomite, which proves that the loading of TiO2 nanoparticles greatly enhanced the porous structure of diatomite.

sections.heading: 3.3. Morphology analysis
sections.text:
Fig. 4. SEM micrographs of the diatomite (a), TiO2 (b), TiO2/diatomite-45% (c), and EDS results of TiO2/diatomite-45% (d).
Fig. 4 presents the SEM micrographs of diatomite, TiO2 and TiO2/diatomite. Fig. 4(a) demonstrates that the diatomite has disc-like morphology with regular pores and smooth
surface. As shown in Fig. 4(b), there is obvious agglomeration of the bare TiO2 nanoparticles because of its nanometer effect. According to Fig. 4(c), the TiO2/diatomite composite also manifest that the diatomite maintains its original disc-like morphology. The surface of
diatomite becomes rougher after the introduction of TiO2 nanoparticles. The image recorded at high magnification (inset of Fig. 4c) further proves that the TiO2 nanoparticles densely and uniformly distributed in diatomite, providing more surface sites for pollutant adsorption and
degradation [56]. The EDS results (Fig. 4d) reveal that the elements Ti, O and Si are
coexisting and distributed uniformly. TiO2 nanoparticles were deposited on the surface of diatomite evenly, avoiding the agglomeration of TiO2, which is in favor of the photocatalytic degradation of TiO2/diatomite composite.
Fig. 5(a) shows a typical TEM image of TiO2/diatomite, in which TiO2 nanoparticles are anchored evenly over the diatomite, which exhibits a favorable combination between
Page 11 of 22
Ac ce
pt ed
M
an
us cr
ip t
9
diatomite and TiO2. In more detail, the enlarged TEM image of Fig. 5(b) shows that the TiO2 nanoparticles have a narrow distribution in average size of 7 to 10 nm. The inset of Fig. 5(b)
showed the HRTEM images of TiO2/diatomite. The clear lattice fringes of TiO2 display interplanar spacing of 0.35 nm, which goes well with that of the (101) plane of the anatase
TiO2 and is in good agreement with the XRD analysis results.
Fig. 5. TEM images of TiO2/diatomite-45%.

sections.heading: 3.4. Surface chemical analysis
sections.text:
XPS analysis was used to characterize the chemical states of TiO2/diatomite.The survey spectrum of TiO2/diatomite (Fig. 6a) clearly shows the signals of Ti, Si and O elements. For pure TiO2, only Ti and O species are confirmed by XPS. The signals of C element can be explained by the adventitious contaminant. The Ti 2p spectrum of TiO2 (Fig. 6b) exhibits two contributions, 2p3/2 and 2p1/2, located at respectively 459.38 and 465.08 eV (with a spin-orbit splitting of 5.7 eV), indicating that the Ti 4+
is the dominant oxidation state in the TiO2 [57,
58]. The shift in binding energy when comparing TiO2 with TiO2/diatomite provides evidence of an interaction between the TiO2 and diatomite. Anchoring the TiO2 on diatomite shifted the Ti 2p3/2 peak from 459.38 eV (TiO2) to 459.18 eV (TiO2/diatomite) and was accompanied by a decrease in 2p1/2 peak from 465.08 eV to 464.88 eV, demonstrating the existence of Ti-O-Si bond. Fig. (c) describes the O1s spectra of TiO2 and TiO2/diatomite. The O 1s spectrum of TiO2 are assigned to lattice oxygen (530.58 eV) and surface hydroxyl oxygen (532.18 eV) [59, 60]. Three signals can be observed in the spectral region of TiO2/diatomite (Fig. 6c). The
Ac
ce
pt ed
M an
us cr
ip t
peak at 533.40 eV belongs to the Si-O-Si bond, which is the characteristic of diatomite [47,
61]. The peaks at 532.49 eV and 530.38 eV can be assigned to surface hydroxyl oxygen and
lattice oxygen, respectively. The calculated results show that theTiO2/diatomite (45.67%) has more surface hydroxyl groups than that of pure TiO2 (30.37%). The shift of O 1s from 530.58 eV (TiO2) to 530.38 eV (TiO2/diatomite) can also proves the presence of Ti-O-Si bond. The peak of Si 2p (103.38 eV) is the characteristic of diatomite.

Fig. 7. UV-vis absorption spectra and band gaps (inset) of the diatomite, TiO2, TiO2/diatomite-45%.

sections.heading: 3.5. Photocatalytic performance
sections.text:
The photocatalytic performance of TiO2/diatomite composite and pure TiO2 was evaluated by decomposing gaseous formaldehyde under UV light (λ=365 nm) irradiation. Fig. 8(a)
shows the photocatalytic activities of TiO2 and TiO2/diatomite composites. The adsorption results showed that the HCHO adsorption reached equilibrium before the photocatalytic
reaction. Obviously, the TiO2/diatomite exhibited the better photocatalytic performance for formaldehyde than pure TiO2. After 180 min irradiation, the degradation rate of TiO2/diatomite for formaldehyde was 90.9%, higher than that of pure TiO2 (80.3%). Compared with pure TiO2, the TiO2/diatomite composite showed larger adsorption capacity for formaldehyde in spite of its lower specific surface area and pore volume. The
TiO2/diatomite composite has more surface hydroxyl groups than that of TiO2, which contributes to its higher adsorption capacity for formaldehyde [62-64]. In addition, the
relatively high dispersion of TiO2 nanoparticles on the surface of diatomite should be another key factor for higher removal effect, which makes more TiO2 nanoparticles can be activated by light. The pseudo-first-order kinetics were used for fitting the degradation process. The
kinetic curves of formaldehyde degradation over samples are plotted and displayed in Fig.
8(b). The kinetic curves tally with the actual situation, indicating that the degradation process
of formaldehyde depends linearly on the concentration of formaldehyde, which is common in
gas-phase reactions with low concentration of pollutants [36]. The rate constant of
Page 14 of 22
Ac ce
pt ed
M
an
us
cr
ip t
12
TiO2/diatomite is 0.011 min -1 , higher than that of TiO2 (0.008 min -1 ). The results suggest that TiO2/diatomite composite has enhanced photocatalytic activities, which should be attributed to the dispersion effect and surface hydroxyl of diatomite.
Fig. 8. Adsorption-photocatalytic degradation (a) and kinetic curves (b) of formaldehyde by TiO2 and TiO2/diatomite-45%.
Fig. 9. Photocatalytic degradation of formaldehyde by P25 and TiO2/diatomite with different TiO2 loading amount.
Fig. 9 shows the photocatalytic degradation rate of formaldehyde by P25 and
TiO2/diatomite with different TiO2 loading amount. The degradation rate of formaldehyde increased with the increase of TiO2 loading amount. However, excess TiO2 loading amount could not enhance the photocatalytic degradation rate of TiO2/diatomite. This may be because that the excess TiO2 on the surface of diatomite make some TiO2 nanopartilces can not be motivated by the light. Degussa P-25 (P25) was used for comparing the photocatalytic
activity with the TiO2/diatomite. The results show that the degradation rate of P25 is little
Page 15 of 22
Ac ce
pt ed
M an
us cr
ip t
13
higher than that of TiO2/diatomite because that P25 has higher dispersity than the samples [41].
Fig. 10. Effect of relative humidity (a), illumination intensity (b) and catalyst amount (c ) on the formaldehyde degradation and the reusability (d) of the TiO2/diatomite composite.
The initial humidity was set as 30%, 45%, 60%, 75% and 90%. The illumination time was
90 min, and the other conditions were used in accordance with section 2.4. The results are
shown in Fig. 10(a), which shows that the humidity has a great influence on degradation of
formaldehyde. The degradation rate of formaldehyde increased with the decline of humidity
from 57.64% (humidity 95%) to 84.26% (humidity 30%). The results demonstrated that high
humidity levels would inhibit the degradation of formaldehyde. It is clear that the higher
humidity would attribute to more water molecules adsorbed on the surface of composite,
which cause a competition adsorption between H2O and formaldehyde [65]. Generally, water molecular participates in photocatalytic degradation, promoting the formation of hydroxyl
radicals [66]. However, superabundant H2O may have an adverse effect on photocatalytic process.
The photocatalytic degradation of formaldehyde was also conducted at different UV
Page 16 of 22
Ac ce
pt ed
M an
us cr
ip t
14
illumination intensity from 8 to 40 W. The illumination time was 90 min. The experimental
conditions including relative humidity, catalyst amount and illumination time were kept at the
initial values. The experimental results are shown in Fig. 10(b). These results clearly
indicated that the degradation rate has an increasing trend with increasing the illumination
intensity. At the illumination intensity of 8 W, the degradation rate of formaldehyde was
55.33% because the limited photons can be used in the photocatalytic process. However, as
illumination intensity increased to 40 W, the formaldehyde removals increased to 78.18%. It
can attribute to the fact that the photocatalyst can produce more electron-hole pairs under
higher illumination intensity, thus promoting the photocatalytic oxidation process.
The effect of catalyst amount was also explored at values of 0.5, 1.0, 2.0, 3.0 and 4.0 g. The
illumination time was 90 min. The experimental results are listed in Fig. 10(c). The
degradation rate presents an upward trend with the increase of the catalyst dosage. When only
0.5 g of composite was used in the degradation reaction, the removal rate was 69.73%, which
should be due to the limited amount of active sites for the adsorption and degradation of
formaldehyde [67]. When the catalyst amount increased to 3.0 g, the degradation rate was up
to 86.20%. Since TiO2/diatomite composite can absorb more photons, more electron-hole pairs were produced, which is beneficial to the degradation of formaldehyde. However, when
the dosage of the composite was up to 4.0 g, the degradation rate was not improved, which
should be due to that the shield effect by excessive amounts of catalyst.
Reusability experiment of TiO2/diatomite was conducted and the results are illustrated in Fig. 10(d). The illumination time was 180 min, and the other experimental conditions were
consistent with the initial values. At the end of each cycle, the composite was taken out and
placed indoors for 12 h. It is observed that the degradation rate of formaldehyde is still over
85% after five subsequent uses, which indicated that the TiO2/diatomite composite has excellent reusability.
Page 17 of 22
Ac ce
pt ed
M an
us
cr
ip t
15
Fig. 11. Free radical experiments for TiO2/diatomite.
The free radical experiments were performed to study the photocatalytic mechanism of
TiO2/diatomite composite. In the experiment, rhodamine B was used as the targeted pollutant and the ammonium oxalate (AO, 1 mM), tert-butyl alcohol (TBA, 1 mM), and benzoquinone (BQ, 1 mM) were introduced as the scavengers of h + , ·OH and ·O2 - , respectively. The TiO2/diatomite (0.1g) was irradiated by the UV light in rhodamine B solution (10mg/L, 100mL). The results (Fig. 11) shows that ·O2 - and h + are the main radicals in the degradation process. The photocatalytic mechanism of the degradation process of formaldehyde can be
proposed as follows: The formaldehyde molecules are adsorbed on the surface sites of
TiO2/diatomite composite. During the the photocatalysis, photoinduced electrons-hole pairs are generated and migrated to the surface of composite, involving radical species (hydroxyl
radicals and superoxide radicals) created. The formaldehyde molecules are gradually oxidized
to CO2 and H2O through the chemical reactions between radicals and formaldehyde.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
The TiO2/diatomite composite photocatalyst was prepared by a simple hydrolysis deposition method using titanyl sulfate as precursor. The TiO2 nanoparticles immobilized onto diatomite uniformly. The XRD analysis indicated that the TiO2 has the anatase phase and crystallite size of ca. 11 nm. The TiO2/diatomite exhibited higher photocatalytic performance for formaldehyde degradation than TiO2. The use of pseudo-first-order kinetics gives a good correlation of the experimental results. The outstanding photocatalytic activity of
Page 18 of 22
Ac ce
pt ed
M an
us cr
ip t
16
TiO2/diatomite should be attributed to the strong formaldehyde adsorption capacity and the good dispersion of TiO2 nanoparticles after the introduction of diatomite. It is confirmed that the lower humidity and higher illumination intensity have favorable influence on the
photocatalytic reaction. Moreover, the TiO2/diatomite composite exhibited excellent stability within five reuses without obvious loss of activity. Overall, this work could provide new
insights into the fabrication of a TiO2/diatomite composite as a promising photocatalyst for indoor air purification.

metadata.abstractText: The TiO2/diatomite composite was synthesized through a mild hydrolysis of titanyl sulfate. The prepared composite was characterized by X-ray diffraction, N2 adsorption-desorption, scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and UV-vis diffused reflectance spectroscopy. The results demonstrate that the anatase TiO2 nanopartilces anchored on the surface of diatomite with Ti-O-Si bonds between diatomite and TiO2. The photodegradation of gaseous formaldehyde under UV irradiation by the TiO2/diatomite composite was s udied under various operating conditions, including relative humidity, illumination intensity and catalyst amount, which have significant influence on the degradation process. The TiO2/diatomite composite exhibited better photocatalytic activity than pure TiO2, which could be attributed to the favourable nanoparticles dispersibility and strong formaldehyde adsorption capacity. In addition, the composite exhibited outstanding reusability over five cycles. The TiO2/diatomite composite shows great promising application foreground in formaldehyde degradation.
